description: Repeated authentication success (firedtimes=180) for user 'susan.gregory' indicates possible use of compromised valid credentials.
Repeated authentication success (firedtimes=179) for user 'susan.gregory' using IMAP suggests credential stuffing or reuse.
Authentication success for 'damian.jordan' with firedtimes=181 suggests reuse of valid credentials across systems.
Repeated successful login detected again for 'damian.jordan' (firedtimes=182); consistent with credential misuse.
Third duplicate log of the same authentication event (firedtimes=183) for 'damian.jordan'; likely reflects a high-volume abuse of valid credentials.
Recurrent successful logins for 'susan.gregory' from same IP with high firedtimes (300); possibly compromised mailbox.
Another successful login (firedtimes=299) for 'susan.gregory'; multiple logs across files suggest attacker persistence.
Authentication success for 'susan.gregory' (firedtimes=298); this may reflect lateral movement or mailbox access abuse.
Login success for 'michael.davis' from internal IP (firedtimes=301); pattern similar to previous suspect logins.
Repeated login (firedtimes=311) for 'michael.davis' from same IP and host; suggests potential valid account abuse.
Successful login to Dovecot via IMAP for user damian.jordan; could indicate valid credential use in lateral movement or persistence.
Repeated successful login by john.hammond from same IP; suggests persistence or automated script activity.
Another successful login for john.hammond from same IP, shortly after prior one; may suggest credential abuse.
Suricata flagged invalid TLS record/traffic; unusual JA3 hash; could suggest obfuscation or custom encrypted traffic.
Invalid TLS handshake with SNI www.state.gov; indicates possible malformed encryption for C2 evasion.
Repeated invalid handshake messages to www.state.gov; may indicate encrypted communication attempts using manipulated TLS.
TLS invalid record/traffic to state.gov, flagged again from local system; repetitive abnormal behavior supports evasion theory.
Snort alert for TLS invalid handshake; same src/dst/port context as Suricata alert, reinforcing suspicion of obfuscated TLS usage.

The alert 'SURICATA TLS invalid record/traffic' suggests malformed or suspicious TLS communication, potentially indicating evasion or C2 tunneling via encrypted channels. JA3 fingerprinting shows a unique TLS fingerprint, possibly linked to malware or unauthorized tools.

The alert 'SURICATA TLS invalid handshake message' suggests abnormal TLS handshake activity which could indicate attempts to bypass inspection or communicate with malicious servers using customized or obfuscated TLS clients.
Suricata detected a TLS protocol violation (invalid record/traffic), which may indicate malformed encrypted traffic, often used to bypass detection.
Alert for an invalid TLS handshake message; attacker might be crafting malformed TLS packets to evade inspection or fingerprint detection.
Repeated alert about TLS invalid record/traffic indicating sustained malformed TLS traffic—potential evasion or reconnaissance technique.
TLS handshake message anomaly from an external IP to internal system suggests possible reconnaissance or probing using malformed encrypted packets.
Authentication success for user 'damian.jordan' via Dovecot IMAP, which may be expected, but frequent logins should be reviewed for account compromise.
Authentication success for 'christopher.friedman'; similar to prior behavior, indicating normal but monitored login activity.
Repeated successful authentication by the same user could suggest automated login behavior or session persistence.
No SSH identification string received; typical of network scanning or probing tools testing open SSH ports without intent to authenticate.
Another system reports same pattern of SSH scan behavior, confirming a likely scan across the subnet.
Continued scan behavior from same source IP against SSH ports; indicates horizontal reconnaissance or vulnerability scanning.
SSHD received connection without identification string, commonly used in SSH scanning to detect open SSH services.
HTTP 403 response to direct GET request; may indicate reconnaissance or misconfigured crawler probing root directory.
Suricata alert for invalid SMTP reply; could be malformed command for exfiltration or scanning.
Client denied by Apache config, typical of probing attempts to discover sensitive directories.
Nmap NSE HTTP probe detected via specific user-agent and custom path. Indicates web app fingerprinting.
403 error in response to Nmap's POST probe to /sdk path, suggesting automated discovery of API endpoints.
Apache denied access to root directory again from same IP as earlier, further indicating scanning or probing.
Attempt to access nmaplowercheck file denied by Apache. Suggests automated vulnerability scan by Nmap.
WPScan tool used to send HEAD request to common WordPress plugin path; attempting to discover plugins.
Multiple HEAD requests to plugin paths with WPScan user-agent detected; typical automated plugin discovery.
Scan targeting WordPress plugin 'click-to-chat-for-whatsapp'; 404 error response; user agent is WPScan, a known security scanner
Scan against non-existent WordPress plugin directory 'cloudflare'; WPScan user agent detected; consistent with automated probing
Probing for WordPress plugin 'cloudflare-flexible-ssl'; 404 error indicates scanning behavior; WPScan fingerprinting
Multiple plugin enumeration attempts from same IP; uses WPScan; targets known vulnerable WordPress plugins in batch
Request for 'bing-webmaster-tools' plugin directory; WPScan signature in user agent confirms scanning tool
Request to WordPress plugin directory using WPScan user-agent suggests automated scanning for vulnerable plugins.
Multiple HEAD requests to different WordPress plugin directories with WPScan user-agent indicate automated plugin enumeration.
Single request probing the /amp/ plugin with WPScan user-agent is consistent with automated scanning behavior.
Pattern of multiple 404 HEAD requests to WordPress plugin directories using WPScan reveals plugin enumeration attempt.
Continued series of HEAD requests to different plugins within a short timeframe by the same IP using WPScan indicates scanning behavior.
Request to a known vulnerable WordPress plugin directory using WPScan, indicating reconnaissance and vulnerability enumeration.
Request for an attachment ID via query string using WPScan tool, often used to enumerate media or post objects in WordPress.
Request for wp-config.php with a malformed suffix, possibly to bypass signature-based protections; indicates scanning for sensitive configuration files.
Scan for different WordPress attachment IDs via WPScan, consistent with media enumeration.
Successful Dovecot login using plaintext authentication method. Could be legitimate but flagged due to frequency or behavioral context.
GET request to a potentially non-existent or internal-only page. Combined with user-agent, this suggests automated scanning.
Request for access-log file, which could reveal sensitive logs if exposed. Indicates reconnaissance behavior.
Burst of requests to URLs matching patterns of directory enumeration, suggesting automated scanning.
GET request to /accountants page during a mass scan. Possibly looking for admin or business-sensitive pages.
Scan targeting /advancedsearch, likely attempting to find pages with query capabilities vulnerable to injection or enumeration.
Multiple sequential 404 errors for suspicious URL paths like /bb, /bbadmin, /bea indicate automated vulnerability or content discovery scan
GET request to '/beheer' returned 404, likely part of brute-force or automated scan targeting admin panels or configuration directories
Attempted access to '/wp-admin/user/webcalendar' suggests probing for known WordPress plugin vulnerabilities or sensitive interfaces
Request to '/wp-admin/user/webcart' indicates likely scan for vulnerable WordPress plugins or pages commonly used in credential harvesting
Attempt to access a protected '.htpasswd_' file, commonly used to store credentials, is a clear sign of probing for sensitive information
Request to 'author.dll' within '_vti_bin' path indicates probing for FrontPage extensions or vulnerable components, often used for reconnaissance or exploitation of legacy WordPress plugins.
404 error on path '/wp-includes/js/tinymce/skins/wordpress/i' indicates automated or brute-force enumeration of WordPress directories or resources.
High volume of 404 errors from same IP requesting varied paths under 'tinymce/skins/wordpress' suggests aggressive directory brute-forcing or resource enumeration.
Request to nonexistent localized image directory 'zh_TW' under WordPress paths; indicative of automated enumeration of language-based plugin files.
Request to unknown image path 'zones' under 'wordpress/images' indicates scanning for specific hidden directories or files on WordPress installs.
Successful Dovecot IMAP login for user 'megan.johnson' from internal IP using PLAIN authentication method; repeated success (firedtimes: 202) could indicate credential misuse or persistence activity.
Duplicate alert for Dovecot IMAP successful login by 'megan.johnson'; firedtimes incremented (203); reinforces account reuse.
Third logging of the same successful IMAP login event for 'megan.johnson' in a short window; may suggest scripted login or session abuse.
New login session from 'megan.johnson' using PLAIN auth again, indicating continued access to system—possible persistence activity.
Same login event from previous line recorded in another log file (mail.info); supports the notion of repeated access tracking.
Third log entry for same login (same timestamp/session id); excessive logging due to multiple log sources, not indicative of new behavior.
Successful login by new user 'damian.jordan' from internal IP; session appears valid but may be suspicious given context of prior alert patterns.
Suricata alert for mismatched HTTP response; could suggest malformed HTTP communication or probing; abnormal HTTP traffic using TCP port 80 as source to high ephemeral destination port.
Snort log entry duplicates Suricata's detection of HTTP response mismatch; redundant evidence of non-standard or malformed HTTP activity.
Successful IMAP login by 'john.hammond'; login over TLS and with method=PLAIN may indicate credential-based access to maintain presence.
SURICATA detected an invalid TLS handshake from external IP. Likely malformed TLS traffic. Could be reconnaissance or evasion attempt.
SURICATA identified malformed TLS record. Possibly part of same anomalous TLS traffic as previous entry; protocol abuse attempt or evasion.
Successful IMAP login using Dovecot; if account access was unauthorized, it may indicate valid account abuse.
PAM authentication failure with repeated login attempt detected on Dovecot. Indicates possible password guessing.
Invalid TLS handshake detected from external IP (Amazon Ads). Likely malformed or unexpected protocol behavior.
Internal IP made a connection triggering invalid TLS handshake detection. Potentially internal scanning, misconfigured software or spoofing.
SURICATA flagged invalid TLS record from Akamai CDN endpoint. Possibly due to encrypted video streaming anomalies.
Internal host initiated connection that resulted in invalid TLS traffic alert. Could indicate malformed packet or legacy client.
Duplicate alert for TLS handshake issue; same src/dst and timestamp. Suggests network anomaly or duplication in logs.
Another log instance of same TLS anomaly. Suricata re-trigger or mirrored log due to Snort/Suricata parallel detection.
User 'www-data' successfully changed UID to another user, possibly indicating privilege misuse or lateral movement
Session opened for user 'phopkins' by UID 33 (www-data), indicating use of valid but potentially misused account
Systemd opened session for user 'phopkins' by UID 0 (root), suggesting elevated access through valid credentials
User 'phopkins' executed a sudo command as root, indicating privilege elevation
Root session opened via sudo, indicating privilege escalation with valid credentials
Session closed for user 'root' – routine sudo session termination
User 'phopkins' accessed /root directory recursively using sudo; indicative of discovery using elevated permissions
User 'phopkins' accessed /etc/shadow via sudo, indicating attempt to collect credential hashes
Root session opened via sudo, confirms privilege escalation with valid account
Session closed for user 'root' – part of normal sudo session lifecycle
